Find Your Team

Some problems are just too big to solve on your own.

The first thing you do when you join Qrackit is join a team. Each team has a name, a mission statement, and a roster where you can see the team members. You can also see what problems this team is currently trying to Qrack!

A Journey And A Destination

Each challenge is like a mountain range waiting to be crossed.

In Qrackit, the mountain range visualizes the players’ progress as they work through the developmental challenge. Each challenge is broken up into four rounds, and each round has four questions. The first round is about defining the causes and effects of the problem.

One Step At A Time

One journey, four questions.

To cross the mountain range, players must create and answer four questions, each one represented by one peak.

Ask The Right Questions.

Here's my idea for a question: "Why don't men who commit street harassment think they are doing something wrong?"
Would phrase it a little better. Maybe "Why do men think it's OK to harass women on the street?"
I vote for the second one!

This is your Base Camp.

Teams meet up at Base Camp to create a question for another team to answer. In order to progress, the team must work together and agree on the best possible question.

Your question will be displayed next to the opposing team’s, and other players will choose between them. If your question is answered, you earn a point for your team, so think carefully about what question you’ll write.

Work Hard, Play Hard

Choose your path.

Teams see two questions, and pick between them through collaborative puzzle-solving. The chasm can be crossed in two different ways. The path your team chooses will select the question at the end of that path.

Working Together For The Answer

I really want to do a video for this. I just got a new camera.
I already have an idea on how to illustrate it. I'm working on a drawing now that I will send.
Do we need to research Lagos first? Does anyone know anyone from Nigeria?

Collaboration is key.

After players select a question, they progress to the next Base Camp and create an answer. Answers could be in the form of a data visualization, a research task, a character portrait, or even an artistic expression.

The Towers of Judgement

Which answer is better?

While you were working on your answer, two other teams were answering the questions you created back at the first Base Camp. Now is your chance to evaluate those answers, and determine which team answered it best. Each answer is rated on its Creativity, Execution, and Real World Impact. The answer with the largest tower at the end of evaluation receives a point for its team.

How Do You Stack Up?

The leaderboard tracks team progress.

After each peak, standings are updated and you’ll see which team is in first place. Teams earn points for creating good questions, submitting good answers. Individual players receive bonuses for individual performance in all aspects of the round.

Round Results

Only one team can win. Will it be yours?

After four peaks have been summitted, the round ends and final points are awarded. The whole process took one week of real time. To fully “qrack” a challenge, players must complete four rounds.

Final Product

A Living, Online Pitch for the Real World.

The content players create through playing Qrack-it are archived, and the winning team gets the ability to create and curate a proposal page that will live online. These pages can be used for crowdfunding, pitching projects to corporations or NGOs, or as a record of the achievements your team worked so hard to bring about during the game.

Engagement Lab

We are an applied research lab dedicated to innovating the ways people participate in civic life and expanding the study of citizenship in a digital era.
